channel.title: Comments on: Don’t start your procedures with SP_
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: How should I rename many Stored Procedures without breaking stuff? - QuestionFocus
item.dc:creator: How should I rename many Stored Procedures without breaking stuff? - QuestionFocus
item.description: […] Based on that list of dependencies, I’d create new stored procedures starting the foundation stored procedures – those with the least dependencies. But I’d mind not to create stored procedures, prefixing the name with “sp_” […]
item.content:encoded: […] Based on that list of dependencies, I’d create new stored procedures starting the foundation stored procedures – those with the least dependencies. But I’d mind not to create stored procedures, prefixing the name with “sp_” […]

item.title: By: Shahzaib
item.dc:creator: Shahzaib
item.description:
Hi George,
I am confused in your wording you said creating stored procedure starts with sp_ is bad practice here my question is that what are the best practice for working with SQL Objects.
item.content:encoded:
Hi George,

I am confused in your wording you said creating stored procedure starts with sp_ is bad practice here my question is that what are the best practice for working with SQL Objects.

item.title: By: vimal nambiar
item.dc:creator: vimal nambiar
item.description:
Hi George
Please check this statement in your blog. "When SQL Server executes a stored procedure, it first checks to see if it is a built-in stored procedure (system supplied). It checks the master database for the existence of this procedure. If the procedure is not found, it will search the user database."
Well in reality,it doesn't check the master database,it only checks the user database. If you expand in SSMS under the user databases,in system procedures folder you will get all the procedures which area exact copy of the system stored procedures in the master database.
You can check for yourself.
item.content:encoded:
Hi George

Please check this statement in your blog.
“When SQL Server executes a stored procedure, it first checks to see if it is a built-in stored procedure (system supplied). It checks the master database for the existence of this procedure. If the procedure is not found, it will search the user database.”

Well in reality,it doesn’t check the master database,it only checks the user database. If you expand in SSMS under the user databases,in system procedures folder you will get all the procedures which area exact copy of the system stored procedures in the master database.

You can check for yourself.

item.title: By: Murtaza
item.dc:creator: Murtaza
item.description: Very good i never know about nameing of Sp is so important.will be carefull in future
item.content:encoded: Very good i never know about nameing of Sp is so important.will be carefull in future

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Irina the problem with a name like this

mnyAnnualSalary

is that when 2 years later you decide to change the datatype to decimal(16,4) most people don’t change the column name since it might break all kind of code so now the mny doesn’t make sense anymore

these days with syntax coloring and intellisense nobody should name their columns or tables like that anymore

Even in .NET Hungarian Notation is not recommended anymore for objects

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
Irina,

There is no REAL problem with using hungarian notation for your column names. No problems as far as the database is concerned.

The problem occurs when humans are expected to write code for the table. If you look at the column names Denis used, they are all self explanatory regarding the data type. There’s an ID (int), a couple names (strings), a BirthDate (DateTime), AnnualSalary (Money). Using a 3 letter prefix on your names does not really help anything, and actually makes the code harder to read.

item.title: By: Irina
item.dc:creator: Irina
item.description: To SQLDenis: What is actually wrong with naming table colomns like that. I have never thought of doing it that way but... does it affect something?
item.content:encoded: To SQLDenis: What is actually wrong with naming table colomns like that. I have never thought of doing it that way but… does it affect something?

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
Just to be clear…

If there’s anything in the dependency list, then those things would need to be modified. The problem is that the dependency list can be incomplete, giving you a false sense of security that you modified all the code that needed to be modified.

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
genomon,

The dependencies list is not always reliable. It has to do with deferred name resolution and the order in which you create your objects.

item.title: By: genomon
item.dc:creator: genomon
item.content:encoded:
“One possible strategy you could use to help resolve this problem would be to rename the procedure, and then create a procedure with the original name. This procedure could write to a log file, and then call the original procedure.”

Another is to right click on the procedure and click on “View Dependencies”.
